title.text: EUDAMU at SemEval-2017 Task 11: Action Ranking and Type Matching for End-User Development

abstractContent.text: The paper describes a system for end-user development using natural language.
Our approach uses a ranking model to identify the actions to be executed followed by reference and parameter matching models to select parameter values that should beset for the given commands.
We discuss the results of evaluation and possible improvements for future work.

introductionContent.text: The goal of the end-user development (EUD) is to provide users of software systems with the tools to create, extend or modify software ().
End-User Development using Natural Language is one of the tasks of International Workshop on Semantic Evaluation.
The idea of using tools for software development more accessible than programming languages has been discussed almost since the beginning of computers.
The concept of programming with natural language commands and its consequences have been considered already in the 70s.
However, only in recent years these ideas could be put into practice with the rapid development of advanced natural language processing methods.
A comprehensive overview of recent trends and achievements in EUD has been presented by.
Although most common solution for EUD problem are various variations on graphical user interfaces, solutions using NLP are also present.

One of the examples is the Koala (later: CoScripter) system (web browser extension), that uses "sloppy programming", i.e. pseudo-natural language instructions, to automate business processes on the web (.

Other systems that use simple natural language commands to achieve programming-like goals, described in recent years, include SPOK, an EUD environment for smart homes, and NaturalMash, an EUD tool for creating web mashups.
This paper describes our system for the end-user development using natural language and reports its performance according to the SemEval 2017 Task 11 evaluation criteria ().

tableCaptions.text: Table 1: Average Micro F1-Score of TF-IDF and Doc2Vec action ranking models.
